objtitle.title: Illustrations to Milton's "Paradise Lost," The Butts Set

objdescid.compdate: 1808The date of composition is established by the inscribed date on objects 1, 3-10, and 12. There is a slight possibility, however, that the second design, "Satan, Sin, and Death: Satan Comes to the Gates of Hell," was executed as an independent composition c. 1806 (see the Editors' Notes, object 2).

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 49.1 cm. x 38.1 cm. and 51.8 cm. x 40.3 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 49.1 cm. x 38.1 cm. and 51.8 cm. x 40.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: pen and water colorObject 2 includes touches of liquified gold.
objinfo.watermark: none visibleMost of the designs are pasted to backing mats.

provenance.name: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (objects 3-9, 11, 12), Victoria and Albert Museum (object 1), Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery (object 2), Houghton Library (object 10).
provenance.date: Objects 3-9, 11, and 12 acquired by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, in 1890; object 1 acquired by the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1869; object 2 acquired by the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery in 1916; object 10 acquired by the Houghton Library in 1966.
provenance.dealer: Various; see the note on provenance below.
provenance.price: Various; see the note on provenance below.
provenance.note: Acquired directly from Blake, and probably commission, by Thomas Butts; by inheritance to his son, Thomas Butts, Jr., in 1845 and by him dispersed. Objects 1-4, 10, 11 offered at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, in separate lots, as follows: lot 177 (object 10, £1.7s. to "Fuller," probably the dealer Joseph or Samuel Fuller), lot 178 (object 3, 17s. to "Butts," indicating that the lot was bought-in if Thomas Butts, Jr. was the vendor), lot 179 (object 4, 10s. to "Butts," probably indicating that the lot was bought-in), lot 180 (object 1, £1.11s. to "Fuller"), lot 181 (object 11, 10s. to "Butts," probably indicating that the lot was bought-in), lot 182 (object 2, £1.11s. to "Fuller"). Objects 3-9, 11, and 12 sold from the collection of Thomas Butts, Jr., Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 139, titled "Nine from Milton" (£17.6s.6d. to John Clark Strange); acquired at an unrecorded time (probably shortly before August 1883) by the dealer Bernard Quaritch, offered in his catalogue 350 of August 1883, in item 13,842, with 23 other works by Blake in three volumes (£1,200), in the same group at the same price in Quaritch's advertising flyer of William Blake's Original Drawings of May 1885 and Nov. 1886, and in Quaritch's General Catalogue of Books of 1887, item 13,842, in the same group (£1,200); offered in Quaritch's 1890 Hand-List of a Peerless Collection of Books and Manuscripts Exhibited to the Bibliophiles of America, item 156, in the same group, including the Butts set of Blake's Comus illustrations (Butlin 528) and a group of 9 of Blake's drawings illustrating the Bible ($5000); this same group of 32 works in three volumes acquired in 1890 by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the gift of Mrs. John L. Gardner and George N. Black. Object 1 still in Fuller's possession in 1863; H. A. J. Munro, sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 24 April 1868, lot 501 (£3.10s. to the dealer P. & D. Colnaghi & Co.); sold 1869 to the Victoria and Albert Museum. Object 2 still in Fuller's possession in 1863; H. A. J. Munro, sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 24 April 1868, lot 500 (£3.12s. to "Cuff," probably R. P. Cuff [or "Cuffe"]); in Cuff's possession in 1876; Charles De C. Cuff before 1907; sold anonymously, Christie's, 19 July 1907, lot 46 (£99.15s. to the dealer Frank T. Sabin); sold by The Rosenbach Company in October 1916 to Henry E. Huntington, with the illustrations to Milton's "On the Morning of Christ's Nativity" ($10,000, according to Rosenbach's receipt in the Huntington archives). Object 10 still in Fuller's possession in 1863; H. A. J. Munro, sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 24 April 1868, lot 502 (£10 to "Kibble," possibly a dealer); Marsden J. Perry at an unrecorded time; sold by Perry in 1908 to William A. White; probably by inheritance to Harold T. White; given to the Houghton Library in 1966 by John H. and Harold T. White.

repository.department: Department of Printing and Graphic Arts
repository.institution: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

desc.objtitle: Satan Arousing the Rebel Angels, object 1 (Butlin 536.1)

objnote.p: The number "697" is inscribed in pen and ink near the lower left corner of the design, just below the palm of the hand in that location. This is one of the Victoria and Albert Museum accession numbers and was added, probably by a curator, when the museum acquired the design in 1869. The museum's collection stamp and another part of the accession number, "6856" in pen and ink, appear in the lower right corner.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design, Satan stands on a large stone in hell, arms raised at 135 degrees, above seven other figures. His mouth is open and he is probably speaking to the other fallen angels. A spear and round sheild lean against a stone to the right of Satan. To the left of Satan, a figure sits on a stone with his body twisted away from the viewer and his right leg extending to the right. Below and to the left, a figure crouches in a cave with a shackle on his right wrist. To the right, a figure lies supine with his arms stretched horizontally; each wrist is bound by a shackle. The head of another figure rises from the flames to the right. His expression suggests fear or pain. To the right, a figure sits with his knees drawn up to his chest and his arms wrapped around his legs. His right wrist is bound by a shackle. The heads of two other figures appear just to the right, over the seated figure's left shoulder. The figures are surrounded by fire, indicating hell. Coloring at the bottom of the design may represent the shore of the lake of fire described in Milton's poem. Thick columns of smoke or dark clouds rise left and right of Satan. Beams of light appear behind Satan, between the columns of smoke or clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design, a nude and muscular Satan (a fallen angel becoming a devil) stands facing forward (right foot on tiptoe) on a large stone. He faces forward with his genitals visible; there is an indication of scales around his genitals. His arms are raised at 135 degrees with his palms vertical and facing outward; the fingers on both hands are spread. His hair is curly and slightly flame-like at the sides of his neck. His mouth is open and he is probably speaking to the figures surrounding him. His knitted brow suggests a combination of melancholy and despair, in spite of his heroic stance.
A spear and a round shield rest against a stone to the right of Satan.

A muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) sits and partly reclines on a stone behind and to the left of Satan. His body faces away from the viewer and is seen from behind. His right leg is bent and extends to the right; his left leg is not pictured. His right foot is prominent. His left arm is bent upward and rests on a stone to the left. His head may rest on his left hand in a position that hints at melancholy. The figure's body twists away from the viewer and leans slightly to the left; his head is turned to the left and faces down. His hair is curly.

In the lower left corner of the design, a muscular nude male (one of the fallen angels) crouches, squats, or lunges forward at the mouth of a cave. His left leg is bent beneath him, knee and foot prominent; his right leg is not pictured. His right arm is bent and braced to support the figure. His right hand is on the ground, palm down, with a shackle on his wrist. His left arm is not pictured, but we can see part of his left hand on the ground, palm down, behind the supine figure's left foot. The figure's body faces forward with his head turned right and up in profile. His head is bent back and he looks up toward Satan. His hair is slightly curly.
A figure crouches or lunges at the mouth of a small cave in the lower left corner of the design.

A nude male (one of the fallen angels) lies supine on the ground below Satan. He is upside down with his head down toward the viewer. He is bearded with long hair. His eyes may be closed (note the absence of pupils); he may be dead. His legs are bent and drawn slightly up; his right leg may lean against his left. The figure's arms are raised horizontally and rest on the ground with the palms down, suggesting a cruciform position. A shackle binds each wrist; at least one chain link hangs from each shackle.

The head and shoulders of a figure (one of the fallen angels, and hence male) appears to the right of the supine figure amidst flames. He faces left and up with his head bent back in profile. His hair is slightly curly and flame-like. His mouth is open with the top row of teeth visible. His expression suggests fear or pain. The rest of his body is not pictured.

A nude male (one of the fallen angels) sits or squats on the ground below and to the right of Satan. His prominent knees are drawn up to his chest and only his right foot is visible. His arms are bent and wrap around his legs. His right hand lies over his left and touches the ground at his ankles. His right wrist is bound by a large shackle that is possibly connected to a chain; his left hand and wrist are not visible. His hair is curly. His head is raised and tilted slightly to the left. His open mouth and knitted brow suggests a combination of melancholy and despair.

The head and left shoulder of a figure (one of the fallen angels) is seen above the left shoulder of the large figure sitting lower right. He faces up and to the left and looks, with eyes raised, toward Satan. His hair and beard are long.

The head of a male figure (one of the fallen angels) appears right of the head of the large figure sitting lower right. He faces up and to the left; he is probably looking at Satan. His hair is spiky and flame-like.
Several figures in the scene stand, sit, or kneel on large stones or boulders. The general impression is of a rocky and fiery landscape of hell.

The scene is marked by tongues of flame, particularly on the right and bottom of the design, and at Satan's feet. Coloring at the bottom of the design may suggest the shore of the lake of fire from Milton's poem.
Dark clouds or smoke rise to the left and right of Satan. Beams of light appear behind Satan, between the columns of smoke or clouds.

desc.objtitle: Satan, Sin, and Death: Satan Comes to the Gates of Hell, object 2 (Butlin 536.2)

objnote.p: There is a slight possibility that this design was executed as an independent composition for Thomas Butts earlier than 1808, possibly even before the 1807 Thomas set of "Paradise Lost" designs, and incorporated into the full Butts set in 1808. It is the only design in the Butts series signed with Blake's monogram, a form he rarely used after 1806, and the only one touched with liquified gold. A lapse of time might also explain the inconsistency of picturing Death (the figure on the right) without a beard, for he is shown with a long, flowing beard in objects 10 and 11 in this series and in all three designs in which he appears in the Thomas series. Butlin page 384 reports that the verso is inscribed, not in Blake's hand, "drawn for Mr. Butts from whom it passed to Mr. Fuller." Neither this nor any other inscription is now visible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Satan and Death stand fighting with Sin between them. Satan, on the left, strides to the right with his arms bent upward. He holds a spear in his raised right hand and an oval shield in his left. Death's body is transparent. He stands with his back to the viewer and leans slightly to the right; with both hands he holds a fiery spear or dart which is pointed at Satan. Sin kneels between the two figures with her arms raised as if to separate them. Her right hand touches the left side of Satan's torso. Below her loins are two coiled serpent's tails and the heads of four hell hounds. A key attached to a chain dangles to the right of Death's left calf. The scene takes place in a chamber or hall with an open passage on the left and a large gate, with a lowered portcullis, on the right. These are the gates of hell. A chain hangs from the upper edge of the design. Fire fills the passage on the left and appears along the lower edge of the design below the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Satan strides to the right, towards the figure of Death, with his legs spread and right foot on tiptoe. He is nude with an indication of scales at his genitals. Satan's mouth is open and his brow is furrowed; his expression suggests anger. We can see the upper row of his teeth. Both arms are bent upward and are raised at approximately 135 degrees. Satan holds a spear in his right hand and an oval shield with belt-like straps in his left hand; he is fighting with (or about to fight with) Death. His body faces forward with his head turned to the right. His hair is curly and slightly flame-like.

Death is seen from behind and stands with his legs spread. His body faces away from the viewer, but his head is turned to the left to face Satan. His body is transparent and he wears a spiky crown. His mouth is open (teeth visible) and his brow is furrowed; his expression suggests anger. His hair is long and flame-like. Both arms are raised above his head with his left arm bent over his head. He grasps a fiery spear or dart with both hands; he is fighting with (or about to fight with) Satan, toward whom he looks.

A nude female representing Sin kneels between the figures of Satan and Death. She faces forward with her head tilted up and to the left. Her mouth is open (teeth and tongue visible) and she may be speaking or howling. She looks up and to the left, eyes raised, toward Satan. Her long, flame-like hair falls behind her shoulders and down her back. Her breasts are prominent. Her right arm is bent upward at a 90 degree angle with her right hand and forearm braced against Satan's chest. Her left arm is raised almost veritcally with her left hand and forearm reaching up Death's left side to his elbow. She is likely pushing the two figures apart in an effort to stop the fight. There are indications of scales at Sin's right hip and upper right leg. Below her loins, two coiled serpents form a spiral extending to the left and right. Their heads are bent back and face up with their mouths open and tongues extended; each serpents' head is topped with a spiky crest. The heads of four hell hounds also appear around Sin's loins. The head left of Satan's left knee faces left. Their mouths are open with tongues extended and teeth visible; they may be barking. The two heads on the right have large, prominent ears. The head second from the right appears to have a furry neck.
A large key attached to a chain appears to the right of Death's left leg. This is likely Sin's key to the gates of hell as described in Milton's poem (2:725).

The scene takes place in a hall or chamber (made of stone?) with an open passage (partly formed of an arch) on the left and a large gate with lowered iron (?) portcullis on the right. These are the gates of hell. A large chain with five links hangs from the upper edge of the design. Fire fills the passage on the left and appears along the lower edge of the design below the figures.

desc.objtitle: Christ Offers to Redeem Man, object 3 (Butlin 536.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ hovers in the center of the design. His body is seen from behind with his head turned to the left in profile. His left leg extends backward. Christ's arms are raised at 135 degrees with his palms facing out (away from the viewer) and his fingers slightly spread. His posture suggests the crucifixion. God the Father sits on a simple throne (raised on a plinth) in the center of the design. His head is down and may rest on Christ's left shoulder, and he touches or lightly embraces Christ with his hands. His posture suggests grief. Beams of light radiate outward from God. A group of four gowned angels fly or hover upside down to the left and right of Christ. Each angel holds a crown which they may be giving or offerering to Christ. A band of clouds separates the upper, heavenly part of the scene from the bottom. Below, Satan hovers or flies to the left on bat-like wings with his body horizontal. His right arm is raised and he holds a spear in his right hand. His shield is strapped to his left arm. His visage suggests a mixture of sorrow and anger.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ hovers in the center of the design. His body is seen from behind with his head turned to the left in profile. He is gowned and has long hair and a beard. His left leg extends backward with the left foot prominent. Christ's arms are raised at 135 degrees with his palms facing out (away from the viewer) and his fingers slightly spread. His posture suggests the crucifixion.

God the Father sits facing forward on a simple throne in the center of the design. He is gowned and appears to have long hair. He bows or bends forward, head down, and may rest his head on Christ's left shoulder. Both arms are bent and rest on his lap. He touches or lightly embraces Christ with his large, prominent hands. God's right foot is visible below the hem of his gown. His posture suggests grief. Beams of light radiate outward from the figure of God.
God sits on a throne with a plinth below.

A group of four gowned angels fly downward or hover upside down to the left and right of Christ. The angels on the left face down and right, while those on the right face down and left. Each angel has a single arm bent and holds a crown; they may be giving or offering the crowns to Christ. The crowns are decorated with leaf-like motifs and sprigs of vegetation. The angels farthest from the viewer have curly hair; the two front-most angels have long hair. One foot of each front-most angel is prominent.
A band of clouds separates the top, heavenly portion of the scene from the bottom portion where Satan appears.

Satan hovers or flies to the left on bat-like wings at the bottom of the design. He is nude. His body is partly horizontal and faces left with his abdomen twisted and lifted up and his head turned back toward the right. His hair is curly and may also be long; a few locks trail above his left shoulder. His left arm is at his side and he holds a shield strapped with belt-like fixtures to his left arm. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees (relative to his body) and he holds a spear in his right hand. His visage suggests a mixture of anger and sorrow.
The sky (or the void or chaos outside heaven?) below the cloud band it is dark or possibly cloudy in the lower right.

desc.objtitle: Satan Watching the Endearments of Adam and Eve, object 4 (Butlin 536.4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Adam and Eve kiss while embracing in Eden. Both figures are nude, and Adam wears a crown or wreath of flowers on his head. The couple sits on a mound or bed of flowers and leaves; Eve rests on a particularly large leaf. Large plants bearing leaves (laurel, according to Milton's poem) and slender branches bearing twenty-two rose blossoms rise left and right of the couple and arch over them. Other plants cover the ground below the couple, including several lily-like flowers. Satan flies or hovers on bat-like wings above Adam and Eve with his body horizontal. A serpent covered in scales encircles Satan's hips, left leg, and right arm. Satan and the serpent (or his own serpent-self) look at each other, much as Adam and Eve gaze at each other below. On the right of the design, the sun is visible on the horizon above the sea, suggesting sunrise or sunset. Beams of light emanate from the sun. The moon appears near the left border of the design along with eight stars.

component.illusobjdesc: Adam and Eve kiss while seated on a bed of flowers. Adam is muscular and nude; he faces forward with his head turned to the left in profile as he looks intently at Eve. Adam wears a crown or garland of flowers on his head. He sits with his right leg drawn up and his left leg bent and extended to the right. His left arm is at his side; he holds a plant with two lily-like flowers in his left hand. With his right arm, Adam holds or embraces Eve. His right hand holds the back of Eve's head with his fingers spread in her hair. Adam's hair is long and slightly curly.

Adam and Eve kiss while seated on a bed of flowers. Eve rests on a particularly large and curly leaf. Eve is nude and faces forward with her head turned up and to the right in profile as she looks at Adam. Her hair is long and curly. She appears to lean against Adam with her right leg slightly bent and her left leg extended downward. Her right arm is at her side and she holds a slender stem with a single rose blossom and three small leaves in her right hand. With her left arm she embraces or holds Adam; her left hand holds the back of Adam's head.

Adam and Eve rest on a mound or bed of buds and flowers—probably roses—and leaves. Eve rests on a particularly large and curly leaf. Large plants bearing leaves (laurel, according to Milton's text) and twenty-two rose blossoms on slender branches rise left and right of the couple and arch above them. Other plants cover the ground below the couple, including several lily-like flowers. The setting is Eden.

Satan flies or hovers on bat-like wings above Adam and Eve. He is nude with curly hair. Satan's body is horizontal with his legs extended to the left. His left arm is bent and is at his side; he points down towards Adam and Eve with his left hand and extended index finger. His head is turned to the left and he looks towards the serpent whose head he holds (or at least touches) with his right hand. Satan is encircled by the serpent (or his serpent-self) as though bound.

A serpent covered in scales encircles Satan's hips, left leg, and right arm. The serpent's head faces right in profile and may be looking at Satan. Their mutual gaze imitates (or parodies) the mutual gaze of Adam and Eve below. The serpent's head is topped with a spiky, flame-like crest and it may be smiling.
On the right of the design, the sun is visible on the horizon above the sea, suggesting sunrise or sunset. Beams of light emanate from the sun.

The moon appears in the upper left of the design. A crescent is illuminated, but we also see the dark part of the moon. Eight stars also appear in the dark night sky. Two stars are in front of, or seen through, Satan's right wing.
There may be distant hills or mountains below the moon.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Adam and Eve lie sleeping on a bed of flowers and leaves with Adam positioned above Eve. Their bodies are supine and lay horizontally across the design with their legs extended to the right. Satan, in the form of a toad, sits or squats on a leaf below Eve and looks up at her. The ground below Adam and Eve is covered in grass and lily-like plants. Large fronds of laurel (?) grow above the figures; some bear buds or fruit (berries?) along the stems. Two gowned angels, Ithuriel and Zephon, fly or hover above Adam and Eve. A pointed halo of light surrounds each angel's head. The left-most angel holds a spear in his right hand; the angel on the right holds a staff or spear. The angel on the left points down toward Adam and Eve with his left hand. A crescent moon and single star appear in the night sky to the right of the angels.

component.illusobjdesc: Adam lies supine on a bed of roses and leaves. He is muscular and nude. His head is bent back in profile and his eyes are closed; he is sleeping. His long, curly hair rests beneath his head. His body stretches horizontally across the design with his legs pointed to the right. Adam's left leg is crossed over his right. His left arm rests at his side while his right dangles limply to the left of Eve's head.

Eve lies supine on a bed of roses and leaves. She is nude. Her head is turned to face out toward the viewer and her eyes are closed; she is sleeping. Her long, slightly curly hair rests beneath her head and falls along both shoulders. Eve's body stretches horizontally across the design with her legs extended together to the right. Her knees are slightly bent. Her arms rest on the flowery bed with the palms down. The fingers of her right hand are slightly spead.

Satan, in the form of a toad, sits or squats on a large leaf below Eve's head. It is seen from behind. The toad appears to have scales or possibly a ridged spine. Its head is bent back and it may look up toward Eve.

Adam and Eve rest on a bed of (rose?) blossoms and leaves. Satan, in the form of a toad, sits on a large leaf below Eve's head; Eve's legs rest on another large leaf. Many smaller (grape?) leaves appear just below the bed of flowers.
The ground below Adam and Eve is covered in grass and arching, leafy plants. Some leaves are spiky; some plants bear lily-like flowers.

Several large branches of laurel (?) grow above the figures in the upper half of the design. At least four arch to the left or right. The plants furthest to the left bear small buds or fruit (possibly berries?) along their stems.

Grape vines with three leaves and a bunch of grapes appear near the center of the design, between Adam and the angels. One forms a loop. To the right and above Adam's legs is some indeterminate vegetation and, near the right margin, two stems with leaves.

Two angels, Ithuriel and Zephon, hover or fly above Adam and Eve. The angel on the left is gowned and has long, curly hair. His body faces left, but his head it turned to the right and he looks toward his companion. The angel's right arm is at his side and he holds a spear in his right hand. His left arm is bent and he points, index finger extended, toward Adam and Eve with his left hand. The figure's left leg is extended to the right; his right leg is not pictured. A pointed halo of light surrounds the figure's head. Blake's design does not distinguish the identities of these two angels.

Two angels, Ithuriel and Zephon, hover or fly above Adam and Eve. The angel on the right has large wings. He wears a gown and has long, slightly curly or wavy hair. He faces left in profile with his head tilted downward to look at Adam and Eve. A pointed halo of light surrounds his head. The figure's right leg is extended down and to the right while his left is bent slightly upward. The figure's right arm is visible only from the wrist down; he holds a spear (the point not pictured) or staff in his right hand. His left arm is bent with his palm held vertically and his fingers slightly spread. Blake's design does not distinguish the identities of these two angels.
A crescent moon and single star appear in the dark night sky to the right of the two angels.

desc.objtitle: Raphael Warns Adam and Eve, object 6 (Butlin 536.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The winged angel Raphael sits in Eden at a vegetative table to the right of Adam and Eve. Raphael's arms are raised at 135 degrees; he points upward with his left hand and points towards the Tree of Knowledge with his right. His wings form a Gothic arch over his head. His lips are slightly parted; he may be speaking. Adam sits on the left side of the design while Eve stands in the center. They are both nude. Adam looks toward Raphael; his arms are bent upward with his hands held near his shoulders and the palms turned out and up. Eve casts her gaze down and to the left toward Adam; she holds a large bowl or cup in her left hand and a bunch of grapes in her right. The table is piled with fruit; two small vegetative vessels (one perhaps an oil lamp with flames) also stand on the table. The ground below the figures is covered with copious vegetation, including leaves, small plants, and flowers. Several grape-like leaves are visible between the legs of the table. Large leafy laurel plants grow left and right of the scene and lily blossoms spring from slender branches that arch over the scene. Small buds or fruit (berries?) also grow among the leaves on both the left and right. Clusters of grapes and spiral grape vines also grow to the left and right of the scene. In the lower left corner of the design, a lily plant arches to the left with two of its flowers bending back to the right. A cluster of rose blossoms rest on the ground in the lower right corner. The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil stands on a hill in the middle distance. There are thorns on the trunk and along many of its roots and branches. Multiple branches arch to the left and right of the central trunk and bear large fruits and several leaves. A serpent coils around the trunk of the Tree of Knowledge with its head resting on the lowest branch on the left. The serpent is covered in scales and has a crest on the top of its head. Two horses and a horned cow or ox stand among the roots of the Tree of Knowledge. A forest of trees appears to the right of the Tree of Knowledge; a stag leaps to the left in front of one of the tree trunks. A flock of sheep stand grazing below the forest, just to the right of Raphael's right hand. Two birds fly close to the ground in the middle distance between Adam and Eve. Above them are two palms, an elephant, an ostrich, a peacock, and a third large stork-like bird with a crest. A (female?) lion stands just above Adam's head, facing right. Above the lion is a lake or river. A waterfall empties into this body of water from a river that winds into the distance. A male lion lies to the left of the waterfall, facing right. Mountains rise in the distance above the river. Two birds fly on outstretched wings above the mountains; two more fly just to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. A few lines of radiance appear to emanate from a soft glow of radiance behind the tree.

component.illusobjdesc: In the lower right half of the design, the angel Raphael sits facing forward and left. He is gowned with long, slightly curly hair; he wears a crown that includes leaf and flame-like decorations. His large wings extend to a point forming a Gothic arch above him. His arms are raised at 135 degrees. With his left hand and extended index finger he points upward while with his right he points toward the Tree of Knowledge in the distance. Raphael appears to be looking at Adam. Some of his multiple wings, their shape and coloring suggesting flames, curve downward. Raphael's bare left foot rests on the ground below his gown. His lips are slightly parted; he may be speaking.

Adam sits on a vegetative chair in the left half of the design. He is nude with curly hair. He faces forward and right and looks toward Raphael. Adam sits with his right leg bent at a 90 degree angle and his left bent at a 45 degree angle; his left foot is on tiptoe. His arms are bent upward with his hands held near his shoulders and his palms turned out and up toward the viewer.

Adam and Raphael are seated on chairs or benches that include vegetation or at least vegetative motifs. The bases or legs include intertwined leaves, vines, and branches (some with loops) of indeterminate vegetation. Rose blossoms or other flowers appear among the branches and some of the intertwined vegetation is suggestive of Gothic art, including arches. The base of the table may be composed of grape-like leaves and vines or branches.

The table is piled with fruit, including at lease one bunch of grapes to the left of Eve's right arm. Two small vessels rest on the table on either side of Eve. The vessel to the right of Eve may be an oil lamp and appears to contain a small fire. The decorations on the open-work bowl or basket behind Eve's right hand suggest a fleur-de-lis motif.

Eve stands or strides forward between Adam and Raphael with her left foot forward and her right foot raised on tiptoe. She is nude and her long, curly hair trails over her shoulders. Her right arm is down at her side and she holds a bunch of grapes in her right hand. Her left arm is bent slightly and she holds a large cup or bowl in her left hand. She faces forward with her head turned down and to the left; she is looking toward Adam.
Eve holds a large bowl or cup in her left hand. The design of the vessel suggests a veined leaf. The handle, suggestive of a serpentine vine, ends in a single loop.

The ground below the figures is covered with copious vegetation, inlcuding leaves, buds, and flowers. Large leafy laurel plants grow left and right of the scene; lily blossoms spring from slender branches and arch over the entire scene. Small buds or fruit (berries?) also grow among the leaves on both the left and right. Clusters of grapes and spiral grape vines also grow to the left and right of the scene. In the lower left corner of the design, a lily plant arches to the left with two of its flowers bending back to the right. A cluster of rose blossoms rest on the ground in the lower right corner. The setting is Eden.

The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil stands on a hill in the middle distance. There are thorns on the trunk and along many of its roots branches. Multiple branches arch to the left and right of the central trunk and bear large fruits and several leaves.

A serpent winds around the trunk of the Tree of Knowledge with its head resting on the lowest branch on the left. The serpent is covered in scales and its head is topped with a spiky crest. The end of its tail, which does not have scales, trails off to the right of the base of the tree's trunk.

A horse stands or walks left of the Tree of Knowledge. Its body faces left, but its head is turned back to the right; it may be looking at the tree. Another horse grazes below and to the right of the tree. It faces left with its head down.
An horned cow or ox stands to the right of the Tree of Knowledge, facing right.
A forest of leafy trees grows to the right of the Tree of Knowledge.
A horned stag leaps to the left in front of the fourth tree trunk from the left, just above a flock of sheep.
A flock of sheep stand grazing to the right of Raphael's left hand.
A small leafy tree grows in the middle distance below Raphael's left hand. A vine with three grape clusters and seven leaves winds around the tree trunk.

Two birds fly close to the ground on outstretched wings in the middle distance between Adam and Eve. Both fly upward; the bird on the left faces up and to the left while the bird on the right faces up and to the right. Both have long tails.
Two palm trees stand in the middle distance between Adam and Eve. They may cast a shadow on the ground below.
An elephant stands behind the two palm trees, facing left. A tusk curves slightly upward from its jaw. Its trunk arches downward.
An ostrich stands to the left of the leftmost palm tree. It faces forward with its head turned to the right in profile. The ostrich has a plume of tail feathers and a prominent beak.
A male peacock stands between the two palm trees with its tail feathers displayed. Its body faces forward with its (crested?) head turned to the left.

A third large bird, possibly of the crane or stork family, stands to the right of the rightmost palm tree. It may be seen from behind with its right wing folded back on top of its tail. The bird's body points slightly to the right with its head turned back to the left in profile. Its head is topped with a crest; its beak is prominent.
Two leafy trees grow in the middle distance left of Adam's head. A serpentine grape vine encirles each tree's trunk; altogether there are four clusters of grapes and perhaps six leaves.
A (female?) lion stands in the middle distance above Adam's head facing right.
In the background to the left, a waterfall flows from a winding river into another river or lake.
A male lion with a mane lies to the left of the waterfall, facing right but with his head turned forward.
One or two trees grow on the cliff right of the male lion and left of the waterfall. Three leafy trees with distinct trunks grow on a cliffside to the right of the waterfall.

A series of mountains rises above the cliffs and river in the left side of the design. The sky is illuminated with a few beams of light that would seem to emanate from the soft radiance behind the Tree of Knowledge.
Two birds fly on outstretched wings above the mountains; two more birds fly just to the left of the Tree of Knowledge.

desc.objtitle: The Rout of the Rebel Angels, object 7 (Butlin 536.7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ in heaven kneels within the disc of the sun. He holds a large bow armed with five arrows pointed at the rebel angels below. Six winged angels fly or hover alongside Christ, three on each side of the sun. All of the angels have their arms bent with their palms facing out toward the viewer. They look toward Christ and some wear an expression of surprise or awe. Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Many of these figures are upside down and are shown in contracted or twisted positions with expressions of pain or fear. Satan is pictured in the center of the group. He is nude and has scales covering his genitals. His arms are bent behind his head. The rebel angels are surrounded by fire.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ appears in the upper portion of the design in heaven, his body circumscribed by the disc or orb of the sun. He is gowned and has long hair and a beard. He kneels with his torso twisted so that his upper body leans to the right. His head faces down as he looks toward the rebel angels. Christ's left arm is extended downward and he holds a large bow in his left hand. His right arm is drawn back and he holds the bowstring taut with his right hand. He is about to shoot at least one arrow.

Christ holds a bow armed with five arrows pointed down at the rebel angels. The shafts of the arrows right and left of Christ's left arm are only faintly visible and disappear entirely within the disc of the sun, though all appear to radiate from the point where Christ holds the bowstring with his right hand. The shaft of the central arrow is not visible.
Christ kneels within the disc of the sun. This upper part of the scene with Christ and the surrounding angels represents heaven.

Six winged angels fly or hover left and right of the sun. The angels on the left face forward and right while those on the right face forward and left; all look toward Christ. The angels on each side closest to the viewer are clearly gowned; indications of collars on the two other angels on the left suggest that they are also gowned. The lowest angel on the left and the central angel on the right have curly hair; the others have long hair. Each of the angels hands are raised near chest or shoulder height with their palms turned out slightly toward the viewer. The hands of the upper angels are partially obscured. The mouth of the lowest angel on the right may be slightly open. Their postures and expressions suggest surprise. The faint outline of an arm appears near the lower right angel's left arm, positioned slightly further from the angel's body. This is likely an earlier version (pentimento) of the figure's left arm.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. On the left edge of the design, the head of a figure is pictured below and to the left of the gowned figure. He faces downward and forward. Only the left side of his face, long hair, and left eye are visible.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The head and shoulders of a fallen angel appear along the left border of the design. His head is turned up and to the right, and he is likely looking at Christ. He has slightly curly hair. His mouth is open, with teeth visible, and his expression suggests a combination of fear and pain. Two curving lines below his neck suggest that he may be gowned.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. In the lower left corner, a nude figure falls upside down. He is seen from behind. His lower body bends or arches to the right and is obscured by the figure to the right. The figure's arms are bent upward and cover his left shoulder. His hair is curly. The figure faces down and his eyes may be closed or lowered sharply.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. A head with curly hair is seen from behind in the lower left of the design, just below the chest of the large descending figure with at least one hand to his face..

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Sixth from the left, a muscular nude male figure falls upside down. His body arches or bends in right profile with his chest and head facing down. Both legs are bent; the figure's left leg is drawn up and the toes on his left foot are curled slightly. His arms are bent upward and he covers his face with his hands. The figure's hair is slightly curly or wavy.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Seventh from the left, a muscular nude male falls upside down. He is seen in part from behind with his hips twisted. The figure's legs are bent and drawn up; the soles of his feet are turned out toward the viewer. The figure's head faces forward toward the viewer. His arms are bent and he clutches the sides of his head with his hands. His eyes are cast down, perhaps looking at the flames below, and his mouth is open with teeth visible. The figure may be howling in pain or fear. He appears to be partly bald with his remaining hair slightly flame-like.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. A figure falls upside down to the right of Satan. He is seen from behind with his shoulders and chest twisted upward. His left leg is bent with the sole of his foot facing the viewer; his right leg is not shown. Both arms are bent. He may touch the left arm of the figure to the right with his right hand. His left hand is held near his face with the palm turned out to the viewer and the fingers slightly spread. The figure's body faces down, but his head is turned to face up; he looks toward Christ. His mouth is open, and he may be howling in pain or fear. He may be partly bald with his remaining hair slightly flame-like.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The fourth figure from the right is a nude, muscular male. He falls upside down and is seen from behind. His body bends to the left. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet are turned out toward the viewer. His arms are bent and his hands are clasped together with the fingers interlaced. Is he praying fearfully? His left cheek may rest on his hands. His hair is slightly flame-like.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. In the lower right corner, a nude male falls upside down. He is seen from behind and is partially obscured by the figure to the left. He is partially bald with his remaining hair slightly flame-like. The figure's arms are bent upward (relative to his body) and his hands appear to clutch the back of his head. The figure's left leg disappears into flames; his right leg is not pictured.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. The head and shoulders of a male figure appear at the right border of the design and just below the uppermost falling angel. The figure is turned with his left shoulder pointed downward and his head facing left. He has curly hair.

Thirteen figures representing the rebel angels fall into flames below Christ. Only the head and shoulders of the uppermost figure on the right are visible. The figure faces forward. His head is turned up and to the left; his eyes are slightly raised and he likely looks toward Christ. His mouth is open, with the tongue possibly visible, and the figure wears an expression of fear or despair. His hair is curly. Lines at the figure's neck suggest the collar of a gown or other clothing.
The thirteen rebel angels are surrounded by flames. The lower reaches of the scene apparently represent hell.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ stands on a large leaf facing left. A halo of light surrounds his head; its diffuse light extends to the left, toward Eve. Christ's right hand is held above Eve with his palm down and fingers slightly spread; he is in the act of forming or creating Eve. Eve hovers above the supine body of Adam. She faces forward with her eyes raised to look at Christ. Her arms are bent upward with her hands together (but not quite touching) in prayer. Adam lies supine on a large leaf with his body horizontal. His head is bent back with his eyes are closed; he is sleeping or is perhaps in a trance. The ground in Eden is covered in grass and many small plants with leaves and flowers. A forest of leafy trees extends left and right across the design above Adam. A crescent moon appears above Eve in the dark night sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ stands facing left in profile with his left foot visible below the hem of his gown. He has long hair and a beard. His left arm is at his side while his right is raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees. His right hand is held above Eve with the palm down and the fingers slightly spread; Christ is in the act of creating or forming Eve. A halo of light surrounds Christ's head; its diffuse light extends to the left, toward Eve. Christ looks at Eve's face.

Eve hovers or floats to the left of Christ with her legs and feet together. She is nude with long hair. She faces forward with her head turned slightly to the right; her eyes are raised to look at Christ. Eve's arms are bent upward in front of her chest with her hands together (but not quite touching) and the palms held vertically as if in prayer.

Adam lies supine on a large leaf at the bottom of the design. His body is horizontal with his head bent back and his eyes closed; he is sleeping or is perhaps in a trance. He is nude with his genitals exposed. His legs and feet extend together. Adam's arms rest at near his side; his right hand rests on the ground with the palm facing up while his left rests with the palm down. His hair is long and curly.

Adam lies on a large leaf at the bottom of the design. The ground around Adam is covered with other vegetation, including grass and several small plants bearing leaves or flowers; the flowers below Adam's feet are lily-like. Christ also stands on a large leaf. The scene is Eden.

A group of trees with visible trunks and large leafy tops appears above Adam and extends left and right across the design. More leaves, probably of trees further in the distance, appear between the tree trunks.
A crescent moon appears above Eve in a dark night sky.

desc.objtitle: The Temptation and Fall of Eve, object 9 (Butlin 536.9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil stands in the center of the design. It has an large, spreading root system and its trunk rises behind Eve and the serpent. The roots, trunk, and some branches are covered in thorns or perhaps, on the trunk, thorny vines. Multiple branches arch overhead bearing large fruits and a few leaves. Eve stands among the roots of the tree. She holds the body of a snake (Satan in his serpent form) wrapped around her hips and cradles its head in her left hand. The serpent's tail coils around her feet and wraps its tail around her left calf. The serpent's mouth is open; a single think line may represent his tongue. It holds a piece of fruit from the Tree of Knowledge in its mouth and offers it to Eve. Eve bends to the right and, with her open mouth, takes the fruit from the serpent's mouth in an eroticized parody of her kiss with Adam in the fourth illustration. Adam stands to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. He is nude and seen from behind. His hands are raised with the palms turned out away from the viewer and the fingers spread. A garland of flowers (roses?) and leaves rests on the ground to the left of Adam's left foot. It probably dropped from his hands. Grass and small plants cover the ground between the roots of the Tree of Knowledge; other indeterminate vegetation (probably bushes or trees) grows in the middle distance left and right of the central tree. A series of mountains rises in the background. The sky is dark and stormy; horizontal lines to the left and right of Adam's head indicate the outlines of clouds. Three bolts of lightning reach from the sky to the ground; two flank Adam and a third appears to the right of Eve and the serpent. The events unfold in Eden.

component.illusobjdesc: Satan, in his serpent form, encircles Eve with coils that suggest a spiral. The serpent's tail wraps around her left calf and ankle and its body climbs upward around her hips and left arm. Its head faces left and up in profile, looking at Eve; its head rests on Eve's left hand. The serpent is covered in scales and its head is topped with a spiky and flame-like crest. Its mouth is open; a single, thin line may represent its tongue. The serpent holds a piece of fruit from the Tree of Knowledge in its mouth and gives it to Eve in an eroticized parody of her kiss with Adam in the fourth illustration.

Adam stands to the left of the Tree of Knowledge. He is nude and is seen from behind. His right leg is extended slightly backward with his right foot on tiptoe. Both of his arms are bent upward with the palms facing out away from the viewer and the fingers spread. His head is turned slightly up and to the left in profile. He looks up, eyes raised, towards the heavens and his mouth is open; his posture and expression suggests surprise. His hair is curly.
A garland of flowers (roses?) or fruit and leaves rests on the ground to the left of Adam's left foot. He may have just dropped the garland.
Adam stands on a mound or a small hill.

The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil stands in the center of the design. It has a large, spreading root system and its trunk rises behind Eve and the serpent. The roots, trunk, and some of the branches are covered in thorns or possibly thorny vines on the trunk. Multiple branches arch overhead bearing large fruits and a few leaves. The scene is Eden.

The ground below the Tree of Knowledge is covered with grass and small leafy plants, the latter possibly with a few flowers. Indeterminate vegetation, probably trees or bushes, grows in the middle distance left and right of the tree.
A series of distant hills or mountains rise left and right of the Tree of Knowledge.

The sky is dark and stormy; horizontal lines to the left and right of Adam's head indicate the outlines of clouds. Three bolts of lightning reach from the sky to the ground; two flank Adam and a third appears to the right of Eve and the serpent. Coloring suggests that each lightning bolt terminates in a blue flame.

desc.objtitle: The Judgment of Adam and Eve: 'So Judged He Man', object 10 (Butlin 536.10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ stands in the center of the design between Adam (to the left) and Eve (to the right) with his arms bent upward and the palms of his hands facing out and up. He is gowned and a faint circular halo of light surrounds his head. Adam stands facing right with his right arm (and presumably his left) bent upward and his hands together in prayer. Eve stands facing left with her hands covering her face, expressing shame. Both Adam and Eve wear loincloths or belts of (oak?) leaves. A serpent slithers along the ground behind the figures with its head, facing left, just left of Adam's raised right heel. The serpent's mouth is open with the tongue extended and teeth visible. The figures stand on a large leaf with small plants below. A forest of leafy trees extends to the left and right of the figures and a band of clouds arches overhead, separating Christ, Adam, and Eve from Death and Sin above. Death, on the left, is gowned and wears a crown. He leans downward to the left of Adam and holds two of three darts or spears in his outstretched hands. Sin is nude and is encircled by two serpent's tails and three hound's heads, their mouths open with prominent tongues and teeth. She pours liquid from two vials to the right of Eve. The scene unfolds in Eden before the expulsion.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ stands in the center of the design between Adam and Eve. His hair is long and he has a beard. A faint halo of light, defined both by coloring and faint circular lines, surrounds his head. He is gowned and faces forward. Christ's arms are bent upward with the palms turned out and up toward the viewer and some of his fingers are slightly spread. His feet are visible beneath the hem of his garment.

Adam stands to the left of Christ with his right leg bent back and prominent right foot on tiptoe. He faces right in profile with his right arm (and presumably his left) bent upward and his hands held together in prayer. His hair is curly. Adam is partly nude; his loins are covered by a loincloth or belt of (oak?) leaves. He may be looking toward Christ.

Eve stands to the right of Christ with her right leg bent and right foot on tiptoe. She faces left in profile with her arms bent upward and her hands covering her face. Her left eye is partially visible and may be closed. Her long, somewhat curly hair falls down her back. Her head is bent down slightly; her posture suggests shame or despair. Eve is partly nude; her loins are covered by a loincloth or belt of (oak?) leaves.

The serpent crawls or winds in an undulating pattern facing left. Scales cover the length of its body. Its head rests on the ground with its mouth open and tongue extended and teeth visible. The serpent's head is topped with a spiky crest.
Christ, Adam, and Eve all stand on a large leaf. The ground below the leaf is covered in arching plants, some with possibly with flowers.
A forest of leafy trees appears in the distance to the left and right of Christ. Many of the trees have visible trunks, several of which split into branches just below their leaves.
An band of clouds arches above Christ, Adam, and Eve, separating them from the figures of Death and Sin above.

The figure of Death flies or hovers above and to the left of Christ. We see only his upper body, head, and arms; his torso seems to dissolve into flames. He faces left and down and may descend toward the figures below. Death is gowned and wears a spiky crown. He has long hair and a beard. Both arms are extended down and to the left and he holds two of three darts or spears in his hands. The triangular shapes left of his head and right arm may be additional spears.

The figure of Sin flies or hovers above and to the right of Christ. We see only her upper body, which is nude, head, and arms. She faces right and down and may descend toward the figures below. Her long, somewhat flame-like, hair trails above her. Both arms are extended downward and Sin holds a vial in each hand; liquid pours from each vial toward the ground to the right of Eve. Sin's eyes are lowered and she looks downward. Two scaled serpent tails coil around Sin. Three dog's heads also appear around her; each has its mouth open with its toungue extended and teeth visible. They may be barking.
Fire rises between the figures of Death and Sin. Darkness in the upper left and right corners of the design may represent smoke.
The scene, or at least the area below the cloud band, unfolds in Eden.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ is crucified upon a cross in the center of the design, raised on a mound or small hill. A halo of radiance surrounds Christ's head. The satanic serpent coils around the base of the cross; its head is nailed to the cross by the same nail that pierces Christ's feet. Death (left) and Sin (right) lay supine at the foot of the cross with their heads down toward the viewer and their arms resting on the ground horizontally. Their eyes are closed; they are dead (that is, vanquished by Christ's sacrifice). Death wears a crown and may be covered by a cloth or drapery. The heads of three dogs, eyes closed and also apparently dead, rest on Sin's torso. The winged angel Michael stands to the left of the cross. He holds a spear in his right hand and wears a crested helmet. His left arm is raised toward Christ with the palm turned out and up. Adam stands to the right of the cross with his left arm bent and his hands held together in prayer. He is nude and seen from behind. Eve rests in a small depression in the earth below the cross. She is nude. Her eyes are closed and she is probably sleeping. The ground below Eve is covered in grass with small flowers and leaves directly above Eve's body and left of her head.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ is sacrificed, crucified upon a cross in the center of the design. He is partly nude with a loincloth covering his hips and genitals. He wears a crown of thorns in his long hair. He is bearded and his head is tilted to the right and down, resting on his left shoulder. His eyes are closed. Christ's arms are raised horizontally with his palms down and fingers spread. His legs are together and are crossed at the ankles with his left foot prominent. A halo of radiance surrounds Christ's head. Christ's salvific blood drips from the wounds on his hands and feet. A wound on the left side of Christ's chest also drips blood.
Christ is crucified upon a wooden cross with three nails in the center of the design.

The satanic serpent coils in a spiral pattern around the base of the cross. The serpent's body is covered in scales and it has a spiky crest on top of its head. Its one clearly pictured eye is closed and its head is nailed to the cross by the same nail that pierces Christ's feet; it is likely dead.

Death lies supine and dead (that is, vanquished) below and to the left of the cross. He is seen upside down with his head bent back to face the viewer and his eyes closed. He may be gowned; lines indicating folds in a cloth or other drapery are visible on his chest and legs. Death is bearded and wears a pointed, spiky crown. His right leg is bent and drawn up. His arms rest on the ground in a position horizontal to his body. This posture suggests an upside-down crucifixion.

Sin lies supine and dead (that is, vanquished) below and to the right of the cross. She is seen upside down with her head toward the viewer and her eyes closed. She is nude, and her long hair fans out on the ground below her head. Her arms rest on the ground in a position horizontal to her body. Her right hand rests palm down on the ground to the right of Adam's feet. Her left arm may rest underneath Death's right shoulder and head. This posture suggests an upside-down crucifixion. The heads of three hounds also rest on Sin's torso with their eyes closed or at least partly closed. They are apparently also dead. A striated, curved shape appears above Sin's torso; this may represent her lower body in serpent form.

The winged angel Michael stands to the left of the cross. He is bearded and wears a crested helmet. He appears partly nude and wears a transparent cape or other drapery over his torso, fastened at his right shoulder. He faces forward with his head turned to the right; he looks up toward Christ. His left arm is bent upward and he points or gestures toward Christ with his left palm turned out, facing the viewer. His right arm is down at his side and he holds a spear in his right hand.

Adam stands below and to the right of the cross. He is nude with curly hair and is seen from behind. His left leg is bent back with the left foot on tiptoe. Adam's left arm is bent; his right arm is not visible, but his hands are held together before his chest in prayer. Adam's head is turned up in left profile with his eyes raised as he looks toward Christ.

Eve lies in a small depression in the earth below the cross. She is nude and her long, curly hair spreads out on the ground below her. Eve lies partly on her side; her body is horizontal with her legs extended together to the right and her torso supine. Her arms are at her sides; her right hand rests on the ground with the palm up while her left palm is down. Her head is tilted up, but her eyes are closed and she is probably sleeping or in a trance.
The ground below below the cross is covered with grass.
The cross is raised on a mound or small hill. Eve lies in a depression in the earth, oddly suggesting a very small valley, a bed, or a grave.

desc.objtitle: The Expulsion of Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden, object 12 (Butlin 536.12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The winged angel Michael strides forward in the center of the design wearing a cloak or other drapery around his shoulders and a helmet with a large crest or plume of feathers. He holds hands with Adam (to the left) and Eve (to the right) as he leads them out of Eden. Adam and Eve both wear loincloths or belts of (oak?) leaves draped over their hips and genitals. Adam bends his right arm upward above his head with the palm held vertically. Eve's left arm is bent upward with the palm turned out. A serpent winds left and right of Michael with its crested head facing left and up and its mouth open with the tongue extended and teeth visible. The ground below the figures is covered in thorny vines and a thistle plants on the left. A swirled, coiled cloud flame appears above the figures. Four cheribum also appear at the top of the design. They are surrounded by flames and ride horses. Four bolts of lightning strike the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: The winged angel Michael strides forward in the center of the design with his left leg and foot prominent. He is partly nude but wears a transparent cloak or other drapery around his shoulders and left arm. He is bearded and wears a helmet adorned with a large crest or plume of feathers. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and he holds hands with Adam (to the left) and Eve (to the right) as he leads them out of Eden. Michael's eyes are raised to look upward. There is an indication of feathers (?) at his genitals.

Adam strides or walks forward to the left of Michael; at least his left foot is on tiptoe. He is partly nude with a loincloth or belt of (oak?) leaves draped over his hips and genitals. His hair is curly. Adam's left arm is bent at his side and he holds Michael's right hand with his left. Adam's right arm is bent upward with the palm held vertically above his head. His head is down and he faces down and to the right in profile. His eyes are lowered and he is likely looking at the serpent below.

Eve strides or walks forward to the right of Michael; at least her right foot is on tiptoe. She is partly nude with her breasts exposed and a loincloth or belt of (oak?) leaves draped over her hips and genitals. Her hair is long and curly. Eve's right arm is at her side and she holds Michael's left hand with her right. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm turned out. Eve's head is down and she faces down and to the left in profile. Her eyes are cast down and she may look at the serpent below. Her mouth is open, suggesting awe or surprise.

A serpent lies slithering on the ground with its crested head turned left and up in profile between Michael's feet. Its mouth is open with the tongue extended and teeth visible. Its scaled body winds along the ground to the left and right of Michael.

Thorn-covered vines appear appear on the ground near the figures' feet. The lowest vine extends to the left and right margins of the design; two more reach from the left margin to the serpent in the center of the design. The vine left of Adam's right leg splits into two branches. A thorny thistle plant with three flowers and a large, spiky leaf appears in the lower left corner; the stems arch slightly towards the center of the design. The setting is east of Eden.
A large, coiled and smoky flame or cloud appears above Michael, Adam and Eve. Tongues of flame and possibly smoke extend upward between the pairs of cherubim and their horses.
Four bolts of lightning strike the ground around Adam and Eve.

The heads of four cherubim appear at the top of the design, with two on either side of the coiled cloud or flame. They probably ride the horses whose heads are pictured below them. The cheribum face forward. Each figure is bearded and has long hair. The figures' hair and beards are somewhat flame-like. The look outward toward the viewer.
The head of a horse appears below each of the four cheribum at the top of the design. They face forward, toward the viewer. The horses' manes or ears are somewhat flame-like.
